title: What Is ChatGPT Doing … and Why Does It Work?

last_post.content:
Given some of the info in this ( https://writings.stephenwolfram.com/2023/02/what-is-chatgpt-doing-and-why-does-it-work/ ) very helpful summary of ChatGPT stuff, I'm starting to think ChatGPT's simple sentence style is not the result of deliberate training for readability and SEO but actually something about the model itself.

The network can figure out the rules of English syntax enough to get by but not enough to consistently generate longer, more complex sentences.

It's tempting to see a connection between this and what *humans* find more readable.

title: ChatGPT sometimes makes up facts. For one law prof, it went too far.

last_post.content:
Asked for examples of sexual harassment at law schools, ChatGPT named a GW law prof accused of touching a student on a class trip to Alaska, citing a 2018 Washington Post story.

The law prof is real. The rest was made up.

We wrote about what happens when AIs lie about you: https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/04/05/chatgpt-lies/

title: Sparks of Artificial General Intelligence: Early experiments with GPT-4

last_post.content:
When intelligent people well versed in the technology and its fundamentals arrive at the conclusion that GPT-4 represents a spark of intelligence, rather than an extremely elaborate but still rote memorization machine, I can't help but feel that we might be witnessing the end of human history: we're going to drown in not disinfo after all, but instead in our own inability to recognize human experience from anthropomorphized simulations.
https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.12712

title: The Three-Legged Stool: A Manifesto for a Smaller, Denser Internet - Initiative for Digital Public Infrastructure

last_post.content:
Social media is under attack, from state legislators, from the US Congress, from reckless billionaires. At @iDPI_umass
we believe something vastly better is possible - conversations we host, moderate, control and learn from. Read our new manifesto here: https://publicinfrastructure.org/2023/03/29/the-three-legged-stool/

We're proposing a vision of social media that's plural, public-spirited and participatory. It embraces existing platforms as well as creates infrastructure for new, smaller, civic-focused conversations. It relies on tools for accessing social media that give us more control over the voices and topics we here, and gives us the ability to audit and interrogate the algorithms we choose to use to filter and sort what we see.

It's not just a manifesto, but a roadmap. Our civic social platform Smalltown is live in Amherst, and the alpha of our aggregator Gobo should be released later this month. Give our paper a read and let us know if and how you want to be part of this ecosystem.

I'm not angry at the journalists who've chosen to remain on Twitter despite its CEO's loud contempt for them -- though I do think it's fair to say that they are supporting him by pouring their work into his site.

Rather, I'm disappointed with them. Deeply disappointed. I hope they will reconsider.

There are already some crazy things out there, like a version of Stable Diffusion that runs in your web browser. https://github.com/mlc-ai/web-stable-diffusion. I wrote something two years ago about why I think WebGPU makes javascript the most interesting programming language out there for data analysts/ML people. https://benschmidt.org/post/2020-01-15-webGPU/ And there's lots of stuff that's become more conceivable since--for instance, a dataframe based on Apache Arrow that does massively parallel data transformations. Chat-GPT in browser.

@tree @tchambers Hey Tristan, you mentioned you wanted a better UX for media.

Have you tried Pixelfed? (@pixelfed https://pixelfed.social/ )

It's optimised for photo and video. It's on the Fediverse, meaning you can interact with everyone on Mastodon. You can view text-only posts from Mastodon if you want (settings -> Timelines -> Show text-only posts).

The developers are actively working on it, including releasing a native iOS and Android app due to hit the app stores in late-April/early May.

The other thing that's worth trying if you haven't already is some of the third-party apps for iOS and Android. Personally, I find Tooot for Android is a much better UX than the native Mastodon app.

For projects like deepscatter, moving to webGPU holds huge possibilities going forward because it means we can do arbitrarily complex calculations directly on the GPU, and pass the results back to the browser. Maps like https://atlas.nomic.ai/map/twitter can render 5,000,000 tweets incredibly fast, but push too much compute to CPU--I have a long and growing list of things that are nearly impossible in WebGL (especially the WebGL 1.0 I'm stuck in for deepscatter...) but that should be quite easy in WebGPU.

Knitted origami
Elizabeth L. Wilmer

"Techniques are presented for embedding horizontal, vertical, and45◦diagonal crease lines into garter stitch knitted fabric. While theseare mostly based on standard lace knitting stitches, the horizon-tal creases use double-cable-crossed elongated stitches in a non-standard way. This crease library suffices to knit a model of a squaretwist, a foundational origami tessellation unit."

title: SoK: On the Impossible Security of Very Large Foundation Models

last_post.content:
On the large AI models, this preprint synthesises what we know so far https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.15259

In short: it is mathematically impossible to have AIs combining the following properties:

1) High number of parameters
2) Robustness to poisoning (e.g. fake data)
3) Privacy-preserving

title: Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback

last_post.content:
"As AI systems become more capable, we would like to enlist their help to supervise other AIs. We experiment with methods for training a harmless AI assistant through self-improvement, without any human labels identifying harmful outputs. The only human oversight is provided through a list of rules or principles, and so we refer to the method as 'Constitutional AI'."

[2212.08073] Constitutional AI: Harmlessness from AI Feedback
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08073#

- low contrast

- missing form input labels (seriously, devs, it's not that hard!!!)

Just updated & committed one of the small examples from the #ThingUmbrella stream last night. And since we didn't really get to the whole reactive canvas rendering part (in detail) I also didn't mention the other recently added _minimal_ example. Both are here:

https://github.com/thi-ng/umbrella/tree/develop/examples/rdom-canvas-basics

https://github.com/thi-ng/umbrella/tree/develop/examples/rstream-sync

Also another related heads up: As a result of working on this new tool, there are several new features and changes related to https://thi.ng/rstream & https://thi.ng/rdom forthcoming. Some of these recent example projects (incl. the trace-bitmap tool and the above canvas demo) are already relying on those. I will do new releases ASAP (in the next few days)...

title: Deep time is, like, really, really deep, man | National Center for Science Education

last_post.content:
The history of Earth as the length of a human’s outstretched arm - representing 4.5 billion years of time.

At this scale, humans emerged so recently that we could be filed off from a microscopic slice at the very tip of a fingernail.

Infographic by Katie Scott from original article in Nautilus. Details at https://ncse.ngo/deep-time-really-really-deep-man #space #time #science #SharedPlanet

title: Slint 1.0: The Next-Generation Native GUI Toolkit Matures

last_post.content:
Just discovered Slint (@slint), A Native GUI Toolkit that works on Desktop (Linux/Win/Mac/WebAssembly) and Embedded (Cortex-M/-A/x86/RISC-V/Xtensa).
One of the co-founders has been the lead developer for QML.
It's written in Rust but also works with C++ and NodeJS.
Very promising!

https://slint-ui.com/blog/announcing-slint-1.0.html

An underrated feature of VSCode for #rstats is unlimited R terminals. Here I can casually work through my check() output (right) in a separate interactive session (left). I do the same with with test output.

A simple time / frustration saver, over being locked to a single R session.

I wrote about another application of this here: https://milesmcbain.micro.blog/2022/10/18/are-you-data.html

title: Validated Names for Experimental Studies on Race and Ethnicity

last_post.content:
In many studies, we use names (like vignettes, or applications).
Names bring a lot of baggage with them.

For example, with ‘Hazel’, you already are forming ideas about age, sex, likely SES etc.

Same with Arthur Worthington III,
or Ozamataz Buckshank.

No name is neutral.

In this study, 4,026 people rated 600 names on numerous attributes.

Full data is available here https://osf.io/ahpvq/

Now you can ‘match’ names on all sorts of characteristics

From @cdcrabtree

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-023-01947-0

The Segment Anything project is really impressive. It's:

- a computer vision task: segment all areas in an image for any class of object & background.
- a paper describing the task, model and dataset
https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.02643
- a very large dataset (11M images!):
https://segment-anything.com/dataset/index.html
- a model published as a running demo (the model runs in the browser):
https://segment-anything.com/demo

The dataset and model where co-developed (model in the loop) to iteratively improve both via active learning.

last_post.content:
Happy to announce that my first-ever #Rstats package, {rtlr}, was accepted to CRAN🥳 🥳 🥳

{rtlr} handles right-to-left languages with ease, so if you happen to be an :rstats: user working with RTL languages (such as Arabic, Persian or Hebrew) then this is definitely for you!

Read all about it in my (also first-ever) blog post, written with #Quarto:

title: What It’s Like To Stop Using Google Search - Debugger

last_post.content:
"What It's Like To Stop Using Google Search"

Most of the time I don't notice a thing ...

... because a surprisingly large fraction of my searches are navigational ("where's the site for that *thing* again?") or informational at a level that's trivially easy for any search service at all

So the actual cost of switching is ... pretty low

(DuckDuckGo's my main search these days)

My essay on it: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551

"Friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://debugger.medium.com/what-its-like-to-stop-using-google-search-fbdf9919c551?sk=723a09d252b9f8558f08e1551b2b6896

title: GitHub - saudiwin/ordbetareg_pack: Repository for R package ordbetareg, used to fit continuous data with lower and upper bounds.

last_post.content: ahhh this new #bayesian ordered beta regression model family (package: https://github.com/saudiwin/ordbetareg_pack; paper: https://doi.org/10.1017/pan.2022.20) is so so neat! I have an outcome bounded at 1 and 32, and the model successfully predicts discrete 1s and 32s, as well as a continuous range in between! #rstats #brms #statsodon

last_post.content:
So are there any good lightweight tools for using your own Mastodon archive? I just want a simple viewer with some basic grep/search and working links to my messages on a live server.

This works pretty well but requires a (simple) install: https://github.com/blackle/mastodon-data-viewer.py

This works without install but was last updated 5 years ago: https://yuzulabo.github.io/Mastodon-Archive-Viewer/
